Situation1: They scan items during a slow afternoon with a few customers in line.
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: A key legislative aide has just called and has ten minutes to talk right now about the bill you are campaigning for.
Story: The register beeps steadily as I scan a loaf of bread, the store unusually quiet for a Thursday afternoon. Only two customers wait behind the woman in front of me, their baskets half-full, their faces patient. My phone, tucked beneath the counter, vibrates insistently. I glance down and see the name: the legislative aide I’ve been trying to reach for weeks. My heart leaps—this is the moment I’ve been waiting for, a chance to push for the bill that could change so much. But I’m on shift, responsible for every cent and every smile, expected to keep the line moving and the drawer balanced. I can’t just walk away, not without risking my job or letting down my manager, who trusts me to keep things running smoothly. Yet if I miss this call, the window for real change might slam shut. My hands tremble as I hand the customer her receipt, my mind torn between the beep of the register and the urgent buzz of my phone, caught between duty to my job and duty to my cause.
